revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

[[File:2016-06-23 Gymnopilus sapineus group 638406.jpg|thumb|202x202px|Gymnopilus Sapineus growing from rotten wood chips.]] {{Taxobox | image = | image_width = 250px | image_caption = ''Gymnopilus sapineus'' | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Cortinariaceae]] | genus = [[Gymnopilus]] | species = '''''G. sapineus''''' | binomial = ''Gymnopilus sapineus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) [[René Maire|Maire]] | synonyms_ref = {{cite web |title= Gymopilus sapineus (Fr.) Murrill |url= http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=277440}} | synonyms ='' Agaricus sapineus'' Fries (1815) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = Gymnopilus sapineus | whichGills = adnate | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=ring | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | sporePrintColor=reddish-brown | howEdible=inedible | }} [[File:Gymnopilus.sapineus.005.COPY.jpg|thumb|165x165px|Gymnopilus Sapineus]] '''''Gymnopilus sapineus''''', commonly known as '''scaly rustgill''', is a small and widely distributed [[mushroom]] which grows in dense clusters on dead conifer wood. It has a rusty orange [[spore print]] and a bitter taste. It is unclear at this time whether this species or its relatives contain the hallucinogen [[psilocybin]]. ==Taxonomy== Speciation in ''Gymnopilus'' is not clearly defined.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/3761920 | last1 = Guzmán-Dávalos | first1 = Laura | last2 = Mueller | first2 = Gregory M. | last3 = Cifuentes | first3 = Joaquín | last4 = Miller | first4 = Andrew N. | last5 = Santerre | first5 = Anne | title = Traditional infrageneric classification of Gymnopilus is not supported by ribosomal DNA sequence data | journal = Mycologia | volume = 95 | issue = 6 | pages = 1204–1214 |date=Nov–Dec 2003 | pmid = 21149021 | jstor = 3761920 | url = http://www.mycologia.org/cgi/reprint/95/6/1204.pdf }} This is further complicated by the macroscopic morphological and ecological similarities between members of the ''G. sapineus'' complex such as ''G. penetrans'' and ''G. navadensis''. [[Michael Kuo]] explicates upon this by speaking of the arbitrary distinction made between ''G. sapineus'' and ''G. penetrans'' made by [[Elias Fries]].[http://www.mushroomexpert.com/gymnopilus_sapineus.html ''Gymnopilus sapineus'' at MushroomExpert] He, at first labeled ''G. penetrans'' to merely be a form of ''G. sapineus'' in 1815, but then recanted and labeled them separate in 1821. ==Description== This mushroom is often mistaken for ''[[Gymnopilus luteocarneus]]'' which grows on conifers and has a smoother and darker cap. Another lookalike is ''Gymnopilus penetrans'' which grows in the same habitat and has minor microscopic differences. '''Cap''': The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|2.5|–|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} across, is convex, and is golden-yellow to brownish orange, darker at the center with a dry scaly surface which is often fibrillose and may have [[wikt:squamule|squamules]]. The cap margin is inrolled at first and curves outward as it matures, becoming almost plane and sometimes developing fibrillose cracks in age. The flesh is yellow to orange and delicate as compared to larger and firmer members of ''[[Gymnopilus]]'', such as ''[[Gymnopilus junonius|G. junonius]]''. '''Gills''': The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are crowded, yellow at first, turning rusty orange as the spores mature, with [[wikt:adnate|adnate]] attachments. '''Microscopic Features''': ''Gymnopilus sapineus'' [[spore]]s are rusty orange to rusty brown, elliptical, rough, and 7 - 10 x 4 - 6 [[micrometre|μm]]. '''Stipe:''': The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|2.5|–|7|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} thick. It has an equal structure or becoming thinner near the base. It is light yellow, bruising rusty brown. The stipe has an evanescent [[veil (botany)|veil]] which often leaves fragments on the upper part of the stipe or the margin of young caps.
'''Taste''': ''Gymnopilus sapineus'' sometimes tastes bitter, sometimes it does not, and it has a fungoid or sweet smell. ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[List of Gymnopilus species|List of ''Gymnopilus'' species]] ==External links== * [http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Gymnopilus_sapineus.html Fungi of California - ''Gymnopilus sapineus''] * [https://mushroomobserver.org/observer/show_name/559 Mushroom Observer - ''Gymnopilus sapineus''] {{Commons-inline|Gymnopilus penetrans|''G. penetrans''}}
{{Commons category-inline|Gymnopilus sapineus|''G. sapineus''}} ==References== {{Reflist}} * Hesler, L. R. (1969). ''North American species of'' Gymnopilus.
